This isn't any type of musk, this is a synthetic component called ambrocenide which is in fact very cheap which helps to reduce the production cost while still allowing to manufacture those "powerhouse" fragrances that fill the room. Unfortunately for us, there are quite a lot of olfactory-impaired individuals who can't detect it in a fragrance which in turn enables these miserly companies to keep getting away with using it. That is also the reason why people say (and genuinely believe) that no one can really hate this and all the hate is undeserved, and why there's no point in trying to argue over this type of fragrance with someone incapable of perceiving it for what it is. What good would it do if you told them ambrocenide smells like formaldehyde, as in, it's its odor profile, not your subjective opinion on it? People will still trust their own nose over you, and they don't care if they walk around smelling like a fruity mortuary as long as they only smell the fruity part. This is the modern perfumery we're stuck with.

So lets break this thing down shall we..... First, I think I should note that Erba Pura smells different from when you first open & spray your brand new bottle, to when it does 10 days later. That said, this fragrance needs a bit of air in order separate its notes. So dont judge it as soon as you take it out the package. Before the fragrance is allowed to open up I can see people having an issue with this "Fruits" note because its indistinguishably Fruity, yet sweet, & indistinguishably Fruity in the same way that Juicy Fruit Gum is. Juicy Fruit Gum doesnt actually contain any fruit juices. Its just a mix of chemicals that trick the mind into believing theres fruit juices within its Sweetness. So I totally get it when reviewers say it smells "Synthetic". Your brand new Erba Pura will indeed smell like a sweet synthetic mess. But thats because its extremely concentrated. But after you give it a few days to open up this is what you'll get. Upon its initial spray you'll be hit with a very authentic, loud, & sharp amalgamation of citrus notes. Specifically, Sicilian Orange, Calabrian bergamot & Sicilian Lemon. Whats adding to that nose piercing sharpness reviewers speak about is a note of Iris. Now, this Iris note wont be clearly distinguishable as Iris until the dry down due to the loud Syrupy Sweetness of the "Fruits" note. Now, when talking about the "Fruits" note, everyone picks up on something different. But to my nose this "Fruits" note smells like Mango's, Peaches, Pear, Passion Fruit, Pineapple, Honeydew Melon, Watermelon, Grapes, & Kiwi, all ripe, & all resting on a platter in their extremely sweet juices. I can also smell Melon Rinds. It smells Tropical. Yet somehow, It wouldnt feel out of place it was worn in Fall or Winter. As the fragrance transitions I can begin to pick up on faint Spices. To be exact, they're the same Spices as in Erba Gold. But again, they're faint. I also smell Amber, & while the Amber smells ambry, it also gives off a subtle Caramel nuance. Similar to the Caramel nuance in Erba Magica. I also pick up on Saffron & subtle Leather nuances, along with a subtle Cypriol note & its Crude Oil nuances. Theres also times where I get a quick waft of that Skank from Erba Oud. But again, these phantom notes will be missed if you've never smelled the Erba Flankers. Its in this moment within the fragrance were it smells very Middle Eastern. Its like you get Erba Magica, Erba Gold, Erba Leather, & Erba Oud all at once... & then its gone. As the fragrance continues on it loses its Middle Eastern influence, & I begin to pick up on Vanilla, Iris, Musk, & what smells like canned Peaches in their syrup, with soft nuances of Melon. .... and for me this is the longest part of the fragrance, & the best part. When the fragrance finally dries down hours later you're left with notes of Iris, & White Musk, & it smells exactly like the Iris/Musk combo in "Skin on Skin" by L'Artisan Parfumeur. Which I also own a bottle of. Erba Pura is Unisex, & its sweet. However, its no more sweet than Nishane's ANI, or Jean Paul Gaultier's UltraMale. Erba Pura can be worn year round. But I'd suggest that if its worn in Summer, its worn on cooler nights. The fragrance honestly smells better in the cool night air. With regards to performance, Erba Pura is a Nuclear Bomb, & it gets stronger as it wears on. So please, for the sake of your own nose dont over spray. Now, for the question that everyone's asking. Does Erba Pura get compliments ??? Erba Pura gets a shit ton of compliments. But personally, to my nose, Erba Pura is not what I would consider a "Compliment Monster". But to the average nose, for some reason, this fragrance just seems to drive em wild. You can wear this fragrance on Dates, to the Club, or to any outdoors event.

Erba Pura, by Xerjoff, smells like Cappy Orange juice with orange pulp in it, fruity candies, powder and a hint of a stale aquatic note. In the opening, all you can smell is a Cappy Orange juice with orange pulp in it. I love this scent, but unfortunately, it evaporates after a few minutes. When it dries down a little bit, the fragrance leaves you with a scent of fruity jelly bean candies, a scent you can often find in a Xerjoff fragrance. In Erba Pura, this scent is accompanied by powdery musk and a stale aquatic note. I didn't hear anyone say they smell that aquatic note too, but to my nose, it is there. It's an aquatic note that I also smell in Megamare by Orto Parisi, I don't know how to describe it in a better way. Considering everything previously mentioned, Erba Pura is not a linear fragrance and you do smell a different perfume after some time, instead of the one you sprayed at the beginning. The perfume does have the general Xerjoff vibe: it smells refined and expensive, you smell classic Xerjoff notes in it and it is very elegant. The longevity and projection are very good. Would I wear it? I think that aquatic scent I am picking up doesn't fit me, but nevertheless, it is a great perfume.
